  • Write a three paragraph essay: you decide the topic, use evidence to support your thesis, add details to back up your thesis
  • Write about something personal
  • Write about someone you admire and tell why
  • Write about someone you dislike and tell why
  • Write a narrative (story) about yourself or someone else

How do you write a paragraph?

Here’s a quick and easy paragraph-writing strategy:

1. Make a plan. 2. Have a purpose and a structure. 3. State your key point (topic sentence). 4. Use examples to support your main point. 5. Use transitions. 6. Make a conclusion.

How to Make a Plan
Brainstorm and choose ideas to put in your paragraph. Make a list of three or four different points. You could make a table with three or four rows, and write down your points in each row. Then, number them in the order you’d like to write about them.
How to have a purpose and a structure?
A paragraph should include a main idea (topic sentence) and supporting examples and details. These supporting sentences should support the topic sentence and make it easy to understand.
How to state your main point?
The topic sentence is the first sentence of your paragraph. It gives the main idea and tells the reader what you will be writing about. It is usually at the beginning of your paragraph. For example, if I am writing about a book, I might write my topic sentence as: “Harry Potter and the Sorcerer’s Stone is an exciting book that children of all ages will like.”
How to use examples to support your main point?
You can use several examples in one paragraph or you can separate them into different paragraphs. Write a 500-word creative story: “You are having a conversation with a friend about the environment.  It turns out they are one of the most important people on the planet because they have a lot of power and are able to make a big difference.  They feel guilty for not doing more and tell you about the new idea they have for improving the environment but aren’t sure if it’s legal.”

Story 1

“Okay, I’ll tell you everything that I know. The truth is that the environment is not something that we humans can take for granted. I am a scientist and have been trying to find a solution for a long time. I wanted to come up with something that will protect the environment and at the same time be useful for humans in some way. When I was working on this project, I discovered something really interesting: a microorganism that can help us create more sustainable products without harming the environment. But here comes the problem: this microorganism only works when certain chemicals are added to the process. Unfortunately, those chemicals are illegal because they are hazardous for humans. I haven’t been able to find a legal way to use them yet. You see, if I could prove that these chemicals are not harmful when added in a controlled environment then there would be no risk for people using our new products. But until now, I have been unable to do so.”

Story 2

“Don’t feel bad about yourself. I know it’s tough, but everyone goes through something like this at some point in their lives. As for me, I started to take care of the environment when I was 8 years old. My parents were very strict about it, so I had no choice but to do my part as well. They made sure that I always recycled, turned off lights when leaving a room, walked instead of drove, and so on. Over time, I realized how important it was to protect the environment. So I decided to create a non-profit organization called “Earth First” and make it my mission in life to help save the planet.”

Write a 500-word creative story: Begin your story with "She was born on a summer night and they called her June, like the month."
Your story should unfold through the characters interactions, decisions, and the consequences of their actions. Aim to weave in common sense lessons and social cues. The narrative should cater to a diverse age group, including at least one dialogue and presenting both positive and negative outcomes.
Do not start with classic sentences like "Once upon a time", be creative. June had been born under the brightest of stars, her parents thoughtfully naming her after the warmest month of the year. As June grew up, she reveled in every opportunity to enjoy the beauty of nature, just as her name suggested - gardening, hiking, swimming, and exploring the wonders of the natural world. However, while she felt deeply connected to the earth around her, June struggled to find true joy in material possessions or superficial things.

One day, while strolling through the forest near her family's home, June stumbled upon an old chest nestled between two gnarled trees. Curiosity piqued, she gently lifted the lid and discovered an assortment of shimmering gems and precious metals. Overwhelmed by excitement and temptation, June began collecting various stones and minerals into a small pouch tied tightly to her waist. After all, if she wasn't going to sell them or keep them for herself, then maybe she could share these treasures with others who might appreciate them more than she did.

On her way back home, June met Thomas, a local boy known throughout the village for his kindness and generosity. He often collected donations for those less fortunate than himself, using his meager funds to help others instead of indulging in luxuries. Excited by her newfound discovery, June eagerly explained to Thomas about her magical treasure chest and how she intended to use its contents for good. Together, they decided to distribute the jewels amongst people who needed them most.

As word spread about June's generosity, more and more individuals flocked to meet the young girl and learn about her remarkable collection of jewels. Before long, the once humble home where June resided became a hub for giving and sharing. Neighbors came together to provide shelter, food, and clothing to anyone in need. Even strangers from faraway lands ventured forth, seeking out June and Thomas for assistance.

Yet amidst the celebration, there emerged a sinister undercurrent. Greedful eyes followed June and her every move, coveting the precious gems she gave away so freely.

Write a 500-word creative story: you are the main character, a 4-year-old boy. It is Christmas Eve and Santa has arrived but he can't seem to remember where he left all his presents. Use the sentence "I found it on the top shelf, in the kitchen, next to your bed" in your story.

I found it on the top shelf, in the kitchen, next to your bed. You're the one who loves Christmas the most. You had to sit on Santa's lap at the mall to make sure he brought you all the presents you wished for. All your presents were under the tree, except one. That one was next to your bed. I went upstairs and opened the box. There was a large bag inside. I started to pull out the presents. There was a doll you wanted. You had been wanting it for a long time. There was also a toy car. It was a monster truck, one that could go real fast. Then there was a video game console. I didn't know what it was, but I knew you'd be happy to receive it. Finally, I took out a puzzle book that looked like it had pictures of fish in it. I looked at the cover, and then put it back in the box.

After I finished opening the box, I ran downstairs. "Santa!" you yelled. You hugged me and kissed me. You wanted to see your presents. I told you to wait until everyone was in the living room. We went into the living room and you opened all the presents that were under the tree. Your eyes lit up as you unwrapped each one. When you got to the last present, you started to cry. I didn't know why you were crying, so I asked you. You said you wanted that present more than anything else. I was very confused. I asked you why you wanted that puzzle book about fish so much. You said you wanted to help catch a fish.

You explained to me that every summer you go fishing with your dad and uncle. They don't let you use a pole because they think you might hurt yourself. They give you a net to catch the fish. You want to use a pole so you can catch your own fish. When I told you that I understood how you felt, you started to laugh. I didn't know why you were laughing, but I knew I was happy because you were happy. I told you that I would buy you a fishing pole and take you fishing this summer

Write a 500-word creative story: it can be fiction or non-fiction, amusing or serious, about whatever you wish, as long as it is inspired by this text snippet: 
“You and your friend both order a pizza with a base price of $10. You get the first two toppings for free, but each additional topping costs $1.50. Your friend gets the first four toppings for free, but each additional topping costs $2. If you both have the same number of toppings, how much did your pizzas cost? Show your work.
Let's call the number of toppings you have x. Since the first two toppings are free, the cost of your pizza is $10 + $1.5(x-2). 
Let's call the number of toppings your friend has y. Since the first four toppings are free, the cost of your friend's pizza is $10 + $2(y-4). 
Since you both have the same number of toppings, we have x = y. 
Substituting this into the cost equation for your pizza, we get $10 + $1.5(x-2) = $10 + $2(y-4). 
Simplifying this equation, we get $1.5x - $3 = $2y - $8. 
Since x = y, we can substitute this into the equation to get $1.5x - $3 = $2x - $8. 
Simplifying this equation, we get $0.5x = $5. 
Dividing by $0.5, we get x = 10. 
So both of you had 10 ”

You both agreed to order the same amount of toppings to ensure an equally fair slice.

To all students, professors, readers, and writers: as we move into the digital world, the importance of literature, creativity, and art are often questioned. Some people may even claim that literature and creativity do not belong in the digital era. This article aims to prove otherwise, as I will discuss the significance of literature and creativity in the digital era, focusing on the importance of story-telling in modern media.
Introduction
The internet has revolutionized the way we live and interact with each other. It has also transformed how we consume information and entertainment. In this modern age, people are constantly connected to the internet through smartphones, tablets, and computers. This constant connection has brought about new forms of storytelling and creativity.
Storytelling is one of the oldest forms of communication. It was used to pass down information and entertainment before writing was invented. In today’s digital age, storytelling has been taken to a whole new level. People now consume stories in a variety of formats, such as websites, social media platforms, and video games. This has led to an increase in creative content and storytelling techniques.
Creative content refers to any form of creative work that is produced on the internet. Creative content can be anything from a simple blog post to a complex video game. The internet has allowed people to express themselves in a variety of ways, which has resulted in an explosion of creative content.
In this article, I will discuss the significance of literature and creativity in the digital era, focusing on the importance of story-telling in modern media. I will also discuss how storytelling can help people connect and understand each other better.
I will argue that literature and creativity are just as important in the digital era as they were in the past. I believe that the internet has given birth to a new wave of creativity and creativity, which has led to an explosion of innovative and unique ideas. In the rest of the paper, I will discuss three reasons why I believe that literature and creativity are essential in the digital age: (a) storytelling is one of the most powerful forms of communication, (b) storytelling allows us to explore our inner worlds and (c) storytelling creates a sense of community.

Write a 500-word creative story: You must write a story that is 500 words or less that incorporates the following: 

 1. A character that is a baker.

 2. A character that makes the wrong food decisions and then ends up sick.

 3. A character that eats a healthy meal to feel better.

As the day begins, you realize that you have an important dinner party to cook for. This is a crucial job that requires your full attention and ability to meet the expectations of your clients. However, it's also the only chance you have all week to see your family, so you want to make sure everything goes smoothly. You start by waking up early in the morning, putting on your apron, and gathering all of the ingredients for the meal. But, after realizing you forgot to pick up some of the essential items on your shopping list, you drive back to the store again. After finally getting everything you need, you head back home and begin cooking. The meal is coming along well, but as soon as dinner time arrives, your family starts showing signs of hunger. They're too hungry to wait any longer, so they end up eating some unhealthy foods before they've had a chance to be cooked. After they finish eating, however, they feel sick due to the lack of nutrients in the food. To help them feel better, you serve them a nutritious meal that you prepared earlier. While they're still recovering from their stomachache, they thank you for providing such a delicious and nutritious meal. You're relieved that your family is feeling better and are proud of yourself for making sure to provide a healthy meal when they needed it most. It's times like these that remind you why you love being a baker.

A. The author woke up early to start cooking.

B. The author had to go back to the store for items.

C. The author forgot to get items off the grocery list.

D. The author had to cook for an important dinner party.

E. The author's family got sick from eating unhealthy food before it was prepared.

F. The author served a nutritious meal to help them recover.

G. The author loved being a baker because of times like these.

H. The author had to make sure to provide a healthy meal when they needed it.

Write a 500-word creative story: 

The girl did not want to hear what her mother had to say. She thought she knew everything about her mother. She had listened to her words of wisdom when she was a child and now that she was eighteen, she had her own ideas. She could not bear her mother’s constant nagging.

She slammed the door and left the house. She met her friends and joined them in a car. The car ride was fun. The boys bought alcohol and the girls drank beer. They sang songs as they drove and laughed at the jokes the boys cracked.

They were on their way to the city, their destination a party. As they neared the city, the girls could not contain their excitement anymore. The boys too were looking forward to it. They had been planning the party for a long time.

They arrived and found the party full of people. The girls walked around and talked to the boys. The music was blaring, and everyone was dancing. Some girls were drinking alcohol, and the boys were buying it for them. Soon, the girls were drunk and in a very drunken state.

Suddenly, the police raided the party. The boys started running, but the police caught some of them. The girls went with them. They were thrown in a police van and taken away. They were charged with drunk driving and underage drinking.

The police let them go when they apologized, and promised that they would not do such a thing again. But the girl was not happy with the outcome. She cried and was angry at her mother and her friends.

She ran home and cried the whole night. She felt betrayed by her mother and her friends. She thought that she had been with the wrong crowd all along. She wanted to change her life and start over.

She told her mother about it the next day. Her mother was happy that she had come to her senses and decided to change. She gave her daughter her love and support and encouraged her to do well in life.

The girl took her mother’s advice seriously and promised to change her life for the better. She stopped hanging out with her friends and started studying hard. She was determined to do well in life and show everyone that she could succeed.

Her mother was proud of her daughter and supported her every step of the way. The girl was happy that she had changed her ways and was determined to succeed in life. She knew that her mother would always be there for her, no matter what.

He didn’t have any friends, or if he did, they were at school and he never even spoke to them during the day. He just walked past them without looking their way. The only thing he seemed to care about was his books.

His mother worked at the hospital in the town next door, and his father worked in town too. But, that was about it. His mother would come home early sometimes and would ask him how he was doing, but she never stayed for long. His father never stopped working. He would get back home late after the sun went down and would go straight to sleep.

Write a 500-word creative story: You live on an alien planet which is dying, but you have the technology to save it. There is a catch though. In order to save the planet, you'll have to sacrifice a part of your body. In exchange, you will gain another superpower.
Write a 500-word creative story: You have just moved into a new neighborhood. On your first day in the neighborhood, you meet a mysterious neighbor that lives next door. However, the neighbor has no name and appears to not recognize anyone. They don't have a house number and no one knows who they are. 
Problem: Write a 1,000-word story that explores a situation slightly related to this text snippet:
“John has 5 apples and eats one each day.  After x days how many will he have left?
If we know the answer to the above question is 3, what is the value of unknown variable x?
John starts with 5 apples.
He eats one apple each day, so after x days, he will have 5 - x apples left.
We are given that he will have 3 apples left, so we can write: 5 - x = 3.
Solving for x, we get: x = 2.
The value of x is 2.
#### 2
The answer is: 2”

The story should unfold through the characters interactions, decisions, and the consequences of their actions. Aim to weave in common sense lessons and social cues. The narrative should cater to a diverse age group, including at least one dialogue and presenting both positive and negative outcomes.
Do not start with classic sentences like "Once upon a time", be creative. In the heart of a bustling city, there was a charming neighborhood filled with families of all shapes and sizes. Among them lived two children named Alex and Jordan. They were best friends who shared everything from secrets to laughter, but most importantly, they shared an unbreakable bond formed by their love for apples.

One sunny afternoon, as they played outside in their backyard, Alex noticed something peculiar about her friend. With curiosity piqued, she asked, "Jordan, why do you always carry five small apples in your backpack?"

Jordan hesitated before responding, "Well, my grandpa gave me these apples to take care of while he's away on business. He said I could eat one every day until he returns."

As days passed, Jordan devoured those apples without hesitation, leaving none behind for others

Write a 500-word creative story: As stated by Dr. Michael Hall, Ph.D. of The Life-Plus Institute, 3, “There are no such things as the big issues. The big issues are made up of many, many, many little issues and all of those little issues are made up of even littler issues. That is how they become so big to us. They become big by the accretion of littler and littler little bits. You can learn this from all of those silly people who go around trying to help you make your life work better. They say, ‘The key to success is not having a big goal. The key to success is having many little goals. Set a little goal each day and get done.’” What do you think of this concept? How can understanding the composition of our big issues impact our ability to resolve them? And most importantly, what little steps will you take to make this possible?
Solution: 200 words – You are making a big issue out of this. Break it down into the little pieces, one little issue at a time, and it will get smaller. I don’t care what it is. It will be smaller. So here you go, the little issues. Number 1: Write a creative story about how to make big issues small. And this is a big issue. Number 2: Think of your big issues and break them down into little bits.

Write a 500-word creative story: the story should include a situation where the main character (student) is faced with an ethical dilemma, i.e., a dilemma in which accepting one option will have positive consequences today but bad consequences in the long run for the student or society, and the other option will have bad consequences today but good consequences in the long run for the student or society. The dilemma should be based on a real event, should challenge readers to question their beliefs, and the resolution should be thought-provoking. The story should be written compellingly and uniquely, not repetitive and mundane.
The story should be rich in language, and avoid dull and repetitive sentences.
The story should have a clear plot and characters with intriguing and compelling traits and dialogues. It should capture the readers' interests with its unique and engaging style. The story should have a strong opening sentence that hooks the readers and makes them want to read more. It should build suspense and tension to keep the readers engrossed throughout the story. The ending should be satisfying and unexpected to make the readers reflect on the events of the story and its significance in their own lives.
Do not start with classic sentences like "Once upon a time", "The world was quiet" or "A long time ago". Be creative. In the small town of Maplewood, there was a man named John who had a successful construction business. He was known for his honesty, fairness, and hard work. One day, a young student named Alex approached John with an unusual request. Alex explained that they were trying to fundraise for a charity and needed some help from John. They wanted him to donate a few materials from his company, which would greatly benefit the charity without costing him anything. However, if John refused to help, it would set back their fundraising efforts significantly.

John listened attentively as Alex presented the case. He knew how important it was to support charitable causes and considered the moral implications of helping or declining their request. However, he also worried about what would happen to his business if people found out that he was giving away free materials. If word got out that he was donating them away for free, potential clients might question whether his company was capable of completing jobs on time and within budget.

Write a 500-word creative story: Begin your story with someone receiving some unexpected news. The story should unfold through the characters interactions. The twist at the end should be ironic.
The answer to this example can be: It was a nameless apparition of a dog that had come to the small town of Collarsville. The fabled dog known as 'The Colonel' was supposed to be a silent ghost that followed the souls of children to the grave. Many parents would use the Colonel to scare children into obedience, but none of them ever saw the actual dog. It was said to look like it had come straight out of an old painting, with its coat white as the driven snow, black trim around the face like sharp sunglasses, and a spiked army cap on its broad skull. The dog had come out of the night as silent as the grave when I had heard it. It had come with it that smell that dogs have after walking on the road; it was a smell that I recognized only after it had come. And then I had heard the barking, long and low and powerful with a resonance like it was being amplified by the very earth itself. Every house around me was the same: dark windows and hidden peepholes with the curtains drawn back. My parents were gone out for the night and my brother in his first year at college, I was still up, waiting for their return. But now I knew that they would never come home; my parents were still in their beds, but there was one thing that had changed. The Colonel had come for me. For a long time, I could only watch it: silent and terrible, it sat on its haunches with its white form and black painted eyes, and it waited with my fate on its tongue like a sword, ready to cut it down. In front of me, between me and my bed, and on either side, it had split the air between everything like a snake ready to strike. It was the stuff of nightmares, and I found myself trembling at the sight of it. My eyes traced over it, looking for some flaw, some error in its form. But there was nothing. And then I heard the footsteps. It was a light pitter patter on the grass outside my window that seemed to get steadily heavier as it moved closer. And I saw the apparition through the glass. I saw the Colonel's mouth turn up at the corners in what looked like a smile, and it looked like something had ignited in its pale

And then I had heard the barking, long and low and powerful with a resonance like it was being amplified by the very earth itself. Every house around me was the same: dark windows and hidden peepholes with the curtains drawn back. My parents were gone out for the night and my brother in his first year at college, I was still up, waiting for their return. But now I knew that they would never come home; my parents were still in their beds, but there was one thing that had changed. The Colonel had come for me. For a long time, I could only watch it: silent and terrible, it sat on its haunches with its white form and black painted eyes, and it waited with my fate on its tongue like a sword, ready to cut it down. In front of me, between me and my bed, and on either side, it had split the air between everything like a snake ready to strike. It was the stuff of nightmares, and I found myself trembling at the sight of it. My eyes traced over it, looking for some flaw, some error in its form. But there was nothing. And then I heard the footsteps. It was a light pitter patter on the grass outside my window that seemed to get steadily heavier as it moved closer. And I saw the apparition through the glass. I saw the Colonel's mouth turn up at the corners in what looked like a smile, and it looked like something had ignited in its pale

Write a 500-word creative story: The 500 words should describe the actions, situations, and scenarios of the characters in the story. The context is that four friends go on a road trip from San Francisco to Los Angeles. 

The four friends were excited to go on a road trip from San Francisco to Los Angeles. Jamie, Alex, Taylor, and Blake decided to make the journey fun by packing snacks, music, and a camera to take pictures along the way. They left early in the morning, and soon after, the sun began to rise. The bright rays illuminated the landscape as the car drove through picturesque forests. 
Blake, who was driving, suddenly noticed an ice cream shop on the side of the road. He suggested they stop for a moment to rest and get some treats. The group agreed and went inside. 
They ordered different flavors and took their time eating them while enjoying the scenery. After they finished their ice cream, Jamie suggested they make a quick pit stop at a nearby gas station to fill up the car. Alex agreed and pulled into the station. 
The friends were in a hurry because they wanted to arrive in LA before nightfall, so they only filled up the car with a half tank of gas. After filling up, the group continued driving down the highway, passing many miles of beautiful open road. 
As the sun began to set, the friends realized they had run out of gas and needed to find a place to sleep for the night. They pulled into the nearest town and found a motel. Jamie called his brother to pick them up in the morning and bring more gas. 
Blake, Alex, Taylor, and Jamie spent the night at the motel and woke up early the next day. They filled up the car with more gas, thanked their brother for his help, and continued on their journey to Los Angeles. 
The friends arrived at their destination and spent the next few days exploring LA before heading home. They all agreed that their road trip had been a success and were excited to plan another adventure in the future. 
The end.

Write a 500-word creative story: You are one of the five most powerful rulers in the world. One day you all get together and decide to play a game. The person who comes out the best after playing this game will become the world's most powerful ruler. What is the game and who do you think will win?

5 days ago


5 days ago
1 Answers

1. If this game is a simple war game, that will turn out to be the dumbest idea of all time! A wise man once said "The way to win a war is not the one who destroys the maximum number of opponent’s but to gain the maximum number of soldiers to your side." You cannot fight a war by yourself no matter how many people you have and no matter how powerful you are. It is teamwork and support from others which you cannot gain unless the general public is in support of you. To get the support you need to make them believe in your ideology and not just force it upon them. As I do not know who you are I will not comment on who will win but if the game is based on strategy and is not just a straightforward war game the answer is it doesn't matter who wins because in the end the person who wins will just be one ruler. In real life all the power is shared by many who have various roles. A ruler is just the commander in chief or the person who gives the idea and has authority for his actions. Everyone else around him who follows his instructions in order to get his work done is equally powerful as him in the grand scheme of things and they do not have the ability to win the game at all. The only person who can win will be the one who the other members choose to let win. Who he or she will be I cannot say. 2. One man against all the rest, I would think that the one man has the upper hand. If there are only five of them, that means he is outnumbered four to one so there is no way he can win the game by himself. If we are taking into account the fact that his enemies all think alike and are united in thought, I would say that it is more than likely that they would find a way to defeat him in his sleep. He would be too busy with his own plan and would not be able to defend himself against such large numbers.

A store is offering a discount of 25% on all items. What is the sale price of an item that originally costs $40?

To find the sale price of an item that originally costs $40 with a 25% discount, you would multiply the original price by the discount rate and subtract it from the original price.

Let's break down the problem step-by-step:

1. The original price of the item is $40.

I opened the door and I was welcomed by the warm air. It smelled like sandalwood and I immediately felt relaxed. The room was full of sunlight, and there were colorful chairs in every corner. My favorite one was the one that had been specially designed for me and looked like a huge orange.

I turned around and saw my best friend Anna standing behind the door. "Come on, I will take you to my room."

We walked through the hall and ended up in a large living room with two couches. On one of them was Anna's mother. "Welcome to the second best place in the world." Her eyes twinkled like a little child, as if she was seeing all the beauty for the first time.

We sat down on the couch, but Anna's mother got up and sat next to me. She leaned close to my ear and whispered, "Come outside and see the view, I'm gonna get you some ice-cream later"

As soon as she went out of the room, Anna's mother whispered to me once more, "I know she won't let you leave here now, but I'm sure she will eventually." Then she added, "If you want to go back, then you must tell me first, and I will help you escape."

I looked at her as if she was insane and asked "What are you talking about?"

"I don't like my daughter marrying someone from another culture, that's why I want to keep you here forever", she answered.

We went outside and Anna took me on a walk around the house. We ended up in her parents' bedroom, where I saw all kinds of exotic treasures from every corner of the world. There were vases and dishes from Asia, carpets from India, wooden figurines from Africa, and many more things. I had no idea where they had come from, but they looked really old and mysterious. I asked Anna about them and she just said that they were souvenirs from her parents' travels. She didn't want to tell me more.

Then we went back to our bedroom. We locked the door and started making love. We wanted to remember this moment forever, because after it

Title: A Journey to Remember

I sat, eyes squinting against the rising sun, staring at a sea of broken glass. A long road of crumbled shards glittered like gold in the light. It was the most beautiful scene I'd ever seen, but my heart was heavy for my fellow travelers. Their homes and dreams shattered beyond repair. 

"Hey, why do you look so gloomy?" My best friend, Salty, shuffled over with a bowl of eggs and bacon. He raised his eyebrows questioningly as he sat down next to me. 

"Well," I sighed, "all this beauty leaves me feeling hopeless."

He chuckled. "I think it's time you took a trip, don't you?" he said knowingly.

My curiosity sparked, I asked, "A journey?" He nodded. "Take me with you, I won't tell anyone!"

Our adventure began the next day, and every step down the glass road revealed something new. It started as just another day until we stumbled across a giant, egg-shaped shell lying in the middle of the road. We circled it carefully, intrigued by its size and shape.

Just then, we heard a familiar voice cry out, "Help!" From inside the shell came a small, fluffy creature looking around nervously. 

"That's Humpty Dumpty," Salty whispered, pointing at the egg.

The creature's eyes widened. "Who are you?" he asked fearfully.

We introduced ourselves and explained our purpose. Humpty Dumpty didn't seem to understand our words but listened intently nonetheless.

Then came a loud crackling sound followed by an explosion of blue sparks that shot up into the sky. A familiar figure appeared amidst the clouds of color. It was an older version of Humpty Dumpty, dressed elegantly in royal blues and greens.

"Welcome, strangers," he said warmly. "You came just in time for my great feast!"

As soon as the words left his lips, everyone rushed toward him, including us. Together, they enjoyed a delicious meal filled with laughter and stories. That night, under the stars,

I knew that her family had been cooking for centuries, and she'd said she'd been saving it until I could cook well enough to understand it. This year, I told her I thought I'd reached that point, so she gave it to me. Some of the recipes have strange ingredients that I can't find in my local stores - or even on the internet. I keep looking, though. I know it must be worth it. I just wish she'd written down instructions."
1: the protagonist is the writer
2: the protagonist wants to cook
3: the protagonist received a recipe book
4: the protagonist thinks that some ingredients are strange
5: the protagonist wants to find ingredients
Output: As a child, I loved spending time with my grandmother in the kitchen, but I could never cook anything, so I never got to see her cook. I always imagined she made really cool dishes, so last Christmas, when I was 18, I asked her for an old family recipe for Christmas. She told me she wanted to wait until I could cook on my own, because a lot of the ingredients are hard to find. She wouldn't give me the book until now, but she did say that a few of them could be ordered online. I'm still doing all of the other things she taught me to do by my lonesome, but I'm pretty sure I can figure out how to make anything with the right ingredients. I'm still a pretty bad cook, but this book could turn me into a good one, just like Grandma. I guess it's time to look for those rare ingredients, and cook something good.

But right before they showed up, my phone rang. I couldn’t help but answer it. It turned out that my dad was at the hospital with some friends and had just been in a car crash. I knew that the most important thing was to be with my dad, and I told my friends I couldn’t make it. My friends seemed a little mad because I had canceled with only an hour’s notice. They also wondered why I hadn’t called them to cancel. Although they seemed a little bit annoyed by it, I knew that they would have done the same for me in my situation. The most important thing was to be there for my dad.”

My niche interest in genealogy was limited to tracing my great-grandparents and their descendants for my school project. Nothing too intense or involved, just basic family tree research. That all changed when I stumbled upon a Reddit thread asking about finding distant relatives through genetic testing.

It sounded like a fun little experiment – order one kit, send your DNA sample, wait for results, maybe connect with someone else from your genetic pool. So I did. After receiving my results, I saw matches for several people across different platforms but paid little attention until one particular match caught my eye. It wasn’t just any ordinary match; it was a cousin from the same ancestral village as me!

My heart skipped a beat. This couldn't possibly be true, could it? But there he was - Mr. X, sharing 100% DNA with me. We exchanged messages, asked questions, and eventually met up in person. Our first meeting felt surreal, like stepping into an alternate universe where everything made perfect sense. Here were two strangers bonded together by our ancestral lineage.

But then came the twist. As our bond grew stronger, Mr. X confessed something devastating: he had been adopted at birth. His biological parents weren't his birth parents after all, and now he felt lost. How can I help someone so close to me discover his roots without betraying the very trust placed in me by my own family?

Write a 500-word creative story: Start your story with "I heard the most incredible thing last week.".
The story should include: a character who achieves their goal, science fictional content, emotional intelligence, an achievement.
Do not start with classic sentences like "Once upon a time", be creative. I heard the most incredible thing last week - I swear it was like something out of a science fiction novel! It all started when my friend Sally came running up to me with a big grin on her face and a stack of papers in her hand. She had just learned about this new thing called the "Magnet Effect" from her teacher, Mr. Thompson.

Mr. Thompson explained that if you put a tiny magnet inside a piece of copper, it could attract other magnets through the metal! And not only that, but the strength of the magnet's force would increase by four times! My mind was blown. How cool was that?!

Sally and I immediately decided we needed to try it out ourselves. We headed over to the school's science lab after class and grabbed a couple pieces of copper wire and some magnets from the supply cabinet. After a few quick instructions from Mr. Thompson, we were ready to give it a shot.

At first, nothing happened. The magnet didn't seem to do anything at all. But then, slowly but surely, the magnet began to move toward the wire. And then, suddenly, it started moving faster and faster, until it was racing across the table, attracted to the copper wire.

We couldn't believe our eyes! This was definitely some real-life magic right here. It turns out that the Magnet Effect is actually a law of physics, which states that magnetic fields pass through materials differently depending on their composition. In this case, the magnetic field was able to travel through the copper wire unimpeded, which allowed the magnet to become more powerful.

After we finished our experiment, I realized that sometimes the simplest ideas can lead to amazing discoveries. Just because something sounds far-fetched doesn't mean it isn't possible. If we keep pushing ourselves and exploring new things, who knows what kind of amazing things we'll find?

In conclusion, thanks to Sally's curiosity and Mr. Thompson's encouragement, I now understand the Magnet Effect and have experienced firsthand the power of science. So remember kids, always stay curious and never stop learning!

Write a 500-word creative story: You are not to reveal your actual story within your word limit. 
  • 500 characters (5,000 bytes): The idea was to have a limit to the size of the file but, considering the characters in the Unicode table, this is not feasible any longer. You can still have a lot of fun with 500 bytes (about 500 characters). The idea is that you don't need to tell a complete story but rather to suggest a story.

  • 5 words: You can use the 5 words in any way you want, so you can even decide to use them all in one word or in any combination. The idea here is to have the words set the mood of the story, so that each reader can interpret it differently. 

  • 3 words, a picture and a GIF: This would be the perfect format for a 6-second video for social media! Here you can have a lot of freedom as to the number of characters. You could use just one character, a series of images or a picture for every sentence. Also, think of what is the perfect amount of words for each case. Remember you need to have at least 3 words. The first idea that pops into your mind could be a picture and a GIF. Or you can choose to use a picture that represents a feeling and use the GIF to show the same idea. I can think of this type of challenge being used to create new, innovative videos for YouTube, Instagram, Snapchat or Vine. 

  • 1 word: This is the most difficult one. You can use one word to tell a complete story. This would be like the one-word writing exercises I did in high school. It is a lot more challenging to tell a story in one word than in 500. I suppose this challenge would be useful to build your skills, or the skills of your students or colleagues. 

To encourage students to take part in the challenge, you can make the first attempt easier and then make the next ones more and more challenging. For example, if they have to send their stories to you, ask them to send a story that they have already written using an example from the genres you chose for them. 

You can use the stories and examples that they send you to create a class anthology. You can also use them to show to other classes as a way to introduce them to the challenge.

And, if you choose to use the challenge

full_output:
Write a 500-word creative story: The only rule is that your story must include all of these words: 
sugar, hat, and cloud

"Please, can you pass me the sugar?" my mom asked me from the kitchen counter.
"Sure," I replied while I put on my favorite cowboy hat.
I walked into the kitchen and reached for the sugar.
"I need that later for my recipe," said my mom.
"Sorry, Mom, I didn't see it sitting here."
"There's something on the window..." I saw a black cloud.
"Let's go outside," said my mom.
We went outside and stood on the porch looking at the sky.
"Oh no! There's a tornado coming!" said my mom.
"Quick, hide in the basement!" I grabbed my dad's tool bag and we ran downstairs.
The tornado ripped through our town. We were safe in the basement.
My mom opened the toolbox and took out a hammer.
"I think I have something we can use for protection in here," said my mom.
We heard a knock on the basement door.
"It's the neighbors," said my mom. 
"Please, can you pass me the sugar?" she asked from the other side of the door.
I looked at my mom with an amused expression. 

After our fun adventure with the tornado, we decided to have dessert. We used the sugar to make a delicious chocolate cake, and we shared it with the neighbors.

The End
Output: 485 words

Write a 500-word creative story: 
The world’s largest ocean, the Pacific, has become the largest desert on Earth. Only a few islands are populated by hardy people who have survived the loss of their land and the extinction of most species of animals and plants. 
Only a few animals can be found at the margins of the oceans where they were once abundant.

Write a 500-word creative story: Write a compelling and insightful story that involves a protagonist, perhaps a challenging situation or event, and insight into human nature. The story can be inspired from your personal life, fictional, or a combination of both.

The story can take place in the past, present, or future, and can be in the first, second, or third person. The setting is up to you, but it should feel realistic or immersive.

Make sure you create complex, dynamic characters that face a meaningful conflict. The outcome of the conflict should be uncertain, and you should leave the reader with something to think about.

Remember: your main goal is to convey an important idea or insight into a particular topic. This can be done by exploring your own thoughts and experiences on this matter, or through clever use of metaphors, allegories, and other creative tools. Your audience will relate better to real-life scenarios instead of unrealistic ones; therefore, try not to use any fantastical elements unless absolutely necessary.

Write down the events that led up to this point. What has happened before? Who are the major characters involved? What is their relationship with one another? What are their goals and motivations? You might want to start by writing a few bullet points about these aspects of your story.

This is called worldbuilding. It helps you get a better understanding of the narrative universe you are creating, as well as the characters inhabiting it.

Next, choose a central conflict for your protagonist(s). What is the main problem they have to overcome? This can be a physical obstacle, emotional struggle, moral dilemma or any other type of challenge. This will provide structure for your story.

You may also need to consider how this problem affects the other characters in your story, and what role they play in resolving it. Remember, conflict is central to a great story. Make sure that everyone has something at stake in the conflict and that they are actively working towards solving it.

Create a strong central character for your story. This is the person (or people) who will be driving the plot forward and dealing with the conflict head-on. Who are they? What do they want? What are their strengths and weaknesses? Think about how their background shapes their perspective on life.

Finally, give yourself time to write. Even if you aren't sure where your story is going, keep writing until you find the rhythm of your own voice. Don't worry about getting everything perfect right away; just focus on building up your narrative arc and developing your characters

Write a 500-word creative story: The story should include: 1) a spark of inspiration (a strange and
unexpected event); 2) a change in the main character due to the spark of inspiration; and 3) a twist at the end.
Sample solution: The sun was shining in the sky, and the birds were singing in the trees. In her garden, Martha was watering the flowers while wearing her favorite white dress. She was very proud of the flowers and the dress, which she had received as a gift on her recent wedding day.

But then, something strange happened. As Martha bent down to water one of the flowers, she felt an unfamiliar sensation in her leg. When she looked down, she gasped in horror: a large black hole had appeared in the middle of her white dress, revealing the dirt underneath. What could it mean? Martha knew that the hole was too big to be caused by any normal object or creature, so she stood up and looked around carefully.

As she did, she heard a noise from above her. A small bird was perched on one of the branches of a nearby tree, holding something shiny in its beak. It was a tiny diamond, smaller than a grain of sand. Martha realized that this must be the cause of the hole in her dress. The diamond must have fallen from the tree during the night, when the birds were sleeping, and landed directly on her dress. But how could this be possible? She hadn't seen any diamonds on the branches of the tree before. Martha decided to take action. She went into the house and returned a few minutes later with a ladder. She climbed up the tree and searched the branches carefully for more diamonds. And there they were - dozens of tiny diamonds, all hidden among the leaves of the tree.

Martha was thrilled! She picked them all up and put them in a jar. She showed them to her husband, who was surprised and delighted. Martha explained to him what had happened, and they both realized that this was a sign of good fortune. They decided to keep the diamonds as a reminder of the day when Martha received the gift of her dress and the beautiful flowers. From that day on, Martha and her husband were always careful when watering their flowers, so that they wouldn't accidentally step on any more diamonds.

Write a 500-word creative story: It was the beginning of a long road ahead. The day was filled with a mixture of emotions: excitement and anxiety, joy and sadness. The sun was shining bright, a sign of new beginnings. We were on our way to a new place, a place full of possibilities and endless opportunities.

We drove through forests and hills, the green scenery never seemed to end. The journey seemed to go on forever. But we kept going, fueled by our dreams and aspirations.

Our destination finally came into sight, it was a small town nestled between mountains and valleys. We pulled over to take a break, we decided to explore the town.

As we walked through the streets, we noticed a small bakery. We decided to stop and buy some treats, to celebrate our journey thus far.

As we entered the bakery, the smell of fresh bread and pastries filled the air. We picked out a variety of treats and brought them back to our car.

We sat in the car eating our treats, when suddenly a small white dog popped out from under our car. We couldn't believe it, we hadn't seen him at the start of our journey, but now he was with us.

We named him Lucky, he was a lucky dog to have found us. We took him home and added him to our family.

From that day on, our journey became even more meaningful. We had a purpose, to take care of Lucky and love him unconditionally.

The sun was still shining bright, but now it shone upon a family, a family filled with love and happiness. A family that had taken a leap of faith, and was now living their dreams.

And so, the journey continues, with new obstacles and challenges around every corner, but with each step taken, we grow stronger and wiser. We are one step closer to reaching our ultimate goal.

And all because of one little dog named Lucky, who showed us that life is about taking risks, and embracing the unknown. That sometimes, all it takes is a leap of faith to create a better future.

So remember, never be afraid to take a chance, because you never know what could happen. You might just find your Lucky!

Write a 500-word creative story: 3rd Place

In the year of the 2.2.22, the future was a wild place.
Machines and technology were everywhere. They made everything faster and easier for people everywhere.
But, this convenience came at a price. There were no jobs. No one had to go to work anymore. Machines did the work. They were efficient and fast, and they didn’t complain. They never got tired. All that was left for people to do was shop.

There were stores for everything. Food. Clothing. Furniture. Toiletries. Electronics.
Everything you could possibly need, wanted, or crave was at your fingertips. A few quick clicks and it was yours. Delivery and pickup was almost instantaneous. You could have anything within the hour.
All of these conveniences changed the way people acted. They acted like spoiled brats. No respect, no manners, no common sense. It was a place of wantonness, where no one was responsible for themselves, and where everything was at their fingertips. There was no need to save, no need to plan, no need to be responsible.
People grew fat. They ate what they wanted and didn’t worry about how they looked. They were lazy, they sat on their fat asses all day, eating and ordering things from their computers. All the machines that did everything for them. They could sit on their butts all day and all they would have to do was order and eat. No one needed to get up for anything.
The world was perfect for all but a few. The only ones who were truly happy were the ones who were in control of the machines. Those who programmed them. Those who made the programs that ran them. Those who kept the machines running. Those who kept the machines going were engineers. They kept everything running. They did all the programming, all the work, all the hard labor that everyone used to do.
The engineers grew to be the most powerful people on the planet. They had all the power, all the knowledge, all the money. They controlled everything. No one could even imagine being able to control the machines the way they did.
But, they didn’t abuse their power. They knew their power. They knew that it could be taken away from them just as quickly as it could be given. They didn’t abuse it. They knew how much work it took to program and make the machines do what they did.
They used their power to help. They used it

full_output:
Write a 500-word creative story: Begin your story with "The house was silent.".

The house was silent
My 4 year old son sat up in bed and shivered. He glanced over at his baby sister who was also awake. I could hear the sound of his feet as he padded over to her crib. He leaned over and pulled her out of the crib and carried her to my side of the bed.

"What are you doing" I asked my son.

"She's scared Mommy. She cries when she's scared."

I looked at my daughter's eyes. They were wide with fright and she was still shivering. "You're such a good big brother," I whispered in my son's ear.

He leaned over and picked her up, then carried her over to the dresser where we had a basket full of clean clothes. He started picking out clothes and carrying them to the bathroom for his sister and his brother to wear. "I'm getting everyone ready for bed," he said to me.

I sat there with tears streaming down my cheeks. I knew my daughter was scared to be in her big sister's room. And I knew my son would do anything he could to help her. He took being the big brother to seriously.

My husband came in shortly after and helped get the other kids ready for bed. I carried our daughter to her room and tucked her into bed. She fell asleep almost immediately.

The 9/11 attacks brought many changes to American lives. In particular, the government enacted security measures in hopes of preventing future terrorism. One such measure was the Patriot Act, which was passed shortly after the 9/11 attacks. The Patriot Act expanded the government's ability to conduct surveillance on American citizens.

Since the attack, there have been many debates about the legality and effectiveness of the Patriot Act. Some argue that it is a necessary tool to protect Americans, while others say that it violates their civil rights. Write a 500-word creative story: You are at a family gathering and a game comes up where people go in a circle and each person has to recite a poem, which everyone will vote for the best. You have 30 minutes to write a poem and recite it as part of the gathering. Go!

The family gathering had never been boring. Well it was, except the part about the old men telling stories about how back in the day they were warriors, when I was just a baby. How they were the heroes, saving the day and the country. How they were loved by all and how the whole world bowed down in front of them as if they were Gods.

That was until Uncle Michael was called to read a poem. Well, read a poem seemed an incorrect term for what he did, or rather tried to do. He looked at the paper with a frown, not really focusing on the words. It was clear that he didn't memorize the poem at all and it was clear that nobody could have read this poem without getting a migraine from the constant fidgeting around in the text. With his eyes glued to the piece of paper, he struggled to get through the first line.

And so the gathering was a bit boring. Until it was my turn to read a poem. I looked down at the text that was supposed to be mine and I could almost feel the pressure on me. I didn't understand how it came about that I was to read a poem, even when I knew I was writing a poem, it was still hard to imagine that I would stand up in front of all of the family and read a poem. Not only was I embarrassed, but I was sure that my work wouldn't be good enough for them. I don't like the idea of them laughing at my work. I took the paper and the stage fright made it even more difficult for me to focus on my work, but I managed to get through the first line.

My eyes were glued to the text and I had a hard time seeing anything else in front of me. Everything looked like a huge blur and I wondered if there was a way out of this situation. I had my eyes closed for a second to shut out all the surrounding people, and for a second I heard the voice of my grandmother. It's hard to explain how she was at all there and I knew that it wasn't just a hallucination of some sort. She was with me in my mind and as I looked at the blank

Write a 500-word creative story: You must describe one day of your childhood. Your story must have: 1. your house number, 2. a favorite food, 3. a nickname, 4. a sport you like to play, 5. a place you like to visit and 6. a pet. This is my third attempt to write a story based on the prompt. I think it's better than the two before it, but I don't feel as if I've really captured what I was hoping for.  I had three more days to try, and maybe I will later.  I just think about it and get depressed.
   My childhood home is on a small cul-de-sac that dead ends into the highway. It's not far from the end, and my house is the second one from the highway end of the cul-de-sac, with an apartment complex on the right side of the road.  It was a very peaceful neighborhood, and the neighbors were pretty nice.
   My family moved into the house when I was 2 years old, so I have some faint memories of being a toddler in my home.  The first thing I remember, however, was my 4th birthday party.  I don't really have a favorite food, but I loved cereal.  My mom always got me the boxes that came in little cars and trucks, which I would play with until I got tired of them. I had a collection of them.  There was one time that I poured some milk on the coffee table by accident, and my mom had to clean it all up.
   I don't remember what my nickname was, exactly, but there are several that are popular.  I always had a problem with my teeth, and the dentist called me "bucktooth" when I was 4 or 5 years old, but I don't really remember what it was.  My mom used to call me a "stinker" or "stinkerbell" when I was really young. When I was a little older, my brother used to call me "dude" or "dudette." And, yes, I have heard that word since it was used in the 1990s song.  That song also reminded me of when I was in college, and I played "Billie's Bounce" by Earth, Wind and Fire for a date

The roar of the audience was deafening. I looked out onto the floor as the last player was announced. There were hundreds of people waiting to hear if I would get to play. My mind raced with all the possible scenarios. What if I was the last person left? What if someone gave up before they got to me? What if I was the first person to make it all the way through to the end? As each player was named and either made it through or got kicked off, I started to feel butterflies in my stomach. The last player was named and he went onto the court and performed like a champion. I was called up next and walked out onto the court with a confident swagger. My heart pounded as I looked out at the crowd. I was nervous but determined to make it through. I got through my first three tricks without breaking a sweat and was feeling good about myself. The crowd was loving every second of it. As I moved onto the next trick, I heard someone in the crowd yelling out “You can do this!”

I looked over at the guy who was yelling and it was my old high school friend. I hadn’t seen him in years but he was obviously rooting for me to make it through. As I got into my final trick, I knew that if I wanted to make it through, I was going to have to give it my all. The pressure was on. I started into my trick and knew almost instantly that something wasn’t right. I looked out at the crowd as I tried to finish my trick and I could see them staring at me with fear in their eyes. I could hear the roar of the audience and the sweat running down my back. My heart pounded as I tried to finish my trick and make it through. I could feel the weight of the whole world on my shoulders and knew I was going to make it through. I pulled off the trick and ran off the court, the crowd roaring in approval. As I got off the court I shook my friend’s hand and thanked him for rooting for me. He looked back at me and said “I always knew you would make it through. That’s what friends are for!” I smiled back and said “Thanks

Write a 500-word creative story: you will need to use the above prompt to get your creative juices flowing. The prompt you choose is entirely up to you. For example, you could create a story about a person who discovers the ability to shape-shift into a werewolf.

The story itself should be a minimum of 500-words long and should demonstrate the use of one of the following: setting, characterization, and dialogue. If you wish, feel free to incorporate any or all of these elements into your work.

The following is an example of a creative work:

Example Prompt: A man is about to be eaten by a lion.

In the dark, I heard footsteps coming closer. I looked around and saw a lion stalking me. I was scared, but I knew I couldn’t run away. Then, I remembered a story from my childhood about a hero who fought off a pack of lions using only his wits. I decided to try it. I sat still and started talking to the lion as if it were my friend.

The lion sniffed me and growled, but then it stopped and looked at me with curiosity. “What are you doing?” it asked.

“I’m just hanging out,” I replied casually. “You’re not going to hurt me, right?”

“No,” the lion said, shaking its head.

“Okay,” I continued. “Let’s have some fun!”

We played together for hours, and when the sun came up, we both went our separate ways. It was then that I realized that sometimes, fear can make us stronger than we think.

I hope you enjoyed this example of how to use a story prompt creatively!

Writing a personal story

If you’d like to tell your own story, follow these guidelines:

  1. Decide what you want your personal story to be about (e.g., growing up in a single-parent household).
  2. Describe the setting (e.g., rural Pennsylvania) and characters (yourself and your parents).
  3. Show, don’t tell: describe the scene through dialogue and action.
  4. Include details about the main character(s), including how they feel, what they do, and why.
  5. Tie everything together with a resolution that answers the question, “what happened next?”

“I’m just hanging out,” I replied casually. “You’re not going to hurt me, right?”

“No,” the lion said, shaking its head.

“Okay,” I continued. “Let’s have some fun!”

We played together for hours, and when the sun came up, we both went our separate ways. It was then that I realized that sometimes, fear can make us stronger than we think.

I hope you enjoyed this example of how to use a story prompt creatively!

Writing a personal story

If you’d like to tell your own story, follow these guidelines:

  1. Decide what you want your personal story to be about (e.g., growing up in a single-parent household).
  2. Describe the setting (e.g., rural Pennsylvania) and characters (yourself and your parents).
  3. Show, don’t tell: describe the scene through dialogue and action.
  4. Include details about the main character(s), including how they feel, what they do, and why.
  5. Tie everything together with a resolution that answers the question, “what happened next?”

Write a 500-word creative story: start writing from this sentence "He'd known he was in love, but not like this." Characters: Sam and Tom

"Is this what love feels like? I've never felt it before, but it is intense!" Sam thought to himself. He was so in love with Tom, but he didn't know if it was the right time to tell him. It wasn't every day that a man was so handsome, and had a great sense of humor.

Sam wanted to make a good impression, so he went out of his way to be a gentleman. He would walk Tom to the door at night, make sure he had everything he needed, and kept a close eye on him.

He'd known he was in love, but not like this. This time was different; he'd never felt so intensely about anyone before.

Sam knew it was time. "Tom, I know you're not ready to hear this now, but I wanted you to know how I feel." Sam looked at Tom for a moment and continued "I've always had a crush on you, and even though I don't think it's mutual yet, I want to be with you."

Tom stared at Sam in shock, not knowing what to say. After a few minutes of silence, Tom finally spoke. "Are you sure? Because I think you're a great person, but I'm just not ready for a relationship right now."

Sam felt a pain in his heart, but he knew he was doing the right thing by telling Tom how he felt.

Sam nodded and said "I understand. Thank you for being honest with me, I appreciate it." Sam felt a little better, even though he was still crushed by Tom's rejection.

He knew it was going to take time, but he knew that one day, Tom would come around.

Sam realized that this was the end of their friendship, and it was time to move on. Although it hurt, he knew he had to do what was best for him.

Sam found it hard to move on, but he knew it was the best thing for him. He started spending more time with his friends, and going out to have fun. Sam knew that it was going to take time, but he was going to be okay.

Write a 500-word creative story: you are stuck inside a room with one door, three windows, and four walls. Can you escape?

To begin, take a step back and think about the problem. What's the goal? To escape, of course. What's the constraint? The only door is locked, and there are windows in three walls. You need to find a way out.

Here's a possible creative story that solves the problem:

You find a strange machine sitting in the corner of the room. Upon closer inspection, you discover that it's a time-traveling device! However, it only takes you back in time by 60 seconds each time you use it. You realize that using this device could help you solve the puzzle.

Step 1: Look for any hidden clues
Take a good look around the room. You notice a small piece of paper stuck to the wall with a number "123" written on it. Interesting, but what does it mean? Suddenly, you remember hearing about a similar code when studying ancient civilizations.

Step 2: Use logic and deduction
The number 123 must refer to something in this room because it's the only clue you've found so far. Since there's a lock on the door, you start thinking about combinations. If you input "123", nothing happens. But wait, maybe you need to enter it in the opposite order - "321". Sure enough, the door opens!

Step 3: Solve the puzzle with help from others
As soon as you step through the door, you find yourself back in the real world. Your friends gather around to congratulate you on solving the mystery. They ask how you did it, and you tell them about the time machine. Surprised, they ask where it is. Unfortunately, you didn't bring the machine with you. Suddenly, you realize that since the machine sent you back in time, perhaps it's still sitting in the room where you started!

You gather your friends and return to the room. Sure enough, there's the time machine waiting patiently. Using the instructions you left yourself earlier (thanks to the power of paradox!), you set the dial to 60 seconds, and voila! Back in present-day reality, armed with the knowledge that sometimes all you need is a little creativity, logic, and imagination to solve even the most complex problems.

Write a 500-word creative story: Your story should include a problem, how it was solved, and what happened at the end. There are no right or wrong answers - be creative!
  • The following is an example of a good story:
    Once upon a time in a land not very far away, a young girl named Sally wanted to bake a cake for her best friend. She had all of the ingredients needed and read the instructions carefully, but she realized she didn’t have enough flour. Sally's dad was at work, so she knew she would have to figure it out on her own.
    So, being very clever, she took two cups of flour and added an extra half cup! Her cake turned out even better than before, making her very happy! The next day, she brought the cake over to her friend's house. They shared a slice together, enjoying each other's company. From that day forward, whenever they saw something that looked interesting, they would try it together – their friendship grew stronger because of it.
  • Example #2:
    There was once a little girl who loved to sing songs by herself. One day, she decided to try singing them with her friend. When they sang together, they realized they sounded amazing! They continued singing together, making beautiful music every time.
  • Example #3:
    Once upon a time, there was a young girl who wanted to learn how to draw. She practiced drawing every day after school, but she felt discouraged because she wasn't very good yet. Then one day, she decided to work hard and improve her skills. After weeks of practice, she finally felt proud of herself when she completed her first drawing without any mistakes! Ever since then, she has never stopped improving, and now she has become a great artist.
  • Example #4:
    Once upon a time, there was a little boy who loved playing soccer. He practiced every day after school, trying to get better at the game. One day, he tried scoring goals against his friends during recess. At first, he struggled to kick the ball properly, but he didn't give up. He practiced every chance he got, learning new techniques and tricks along the way. Soon enough, he became confident enough to score a goal during the school football match, which made him feel proud and accomplished.

Your story should include: 
- Niche interests or humor: dive into specific hobbies, interests, or humorous situations 
- An unexpected plot twist or engaging conflict: introduce a relatable yet challenging situation or dilemma that the author faced. 
- Reflection and insight: end with a resolution that offers a new understanding, a sense of community, or a personal revelation, much like the conclusions drawn in forum discussions.
Start the story right away. Do not start with sentences like  "Once upon a time" as this is a reddit post and not a novel, you should also avoid starting with classic sentences like "A few years ago" or "A few years back", be creative. I never thought I'd find myself discussing mathematical concepts on a gaming subreddit, but here we are. It all started when I decided to create a custom player character for a tabletop RPG based on my niche interest - programming and mathematics. Little did I know that my obsession with algorithms would lead me down a rabbit hole of mathematical problems and hilarious gaming stories.

One day, our party encountered a room filled with crates containing various items. To claim the loot, we needed to solve a seemingly impossible riddle: each crate held a combination lock that required us to open it before taking anything out. The combinations were determined by the first ten positive integers (1 through 10), where the nth integer represented the nth power of the number preceding it. Confused? Here's an example using the third crate:

* Its code is 2^(3-1).
* Calculate 2^3 - 2^1 = 8 - 2 = 6.
* Thus, the combination for the third crate is 6.

Our party quickly realized that brute force wouldn't suffice; instead, we needed to rely on our collective knowledge of mathematical concepts. This presented quite a challenge, especially since some members had left us stranded in the middle of the dungeon without their trusty calculator! But wait, there's more...just when we thought things couldn't get any crazier, the mysterious Dungeon Master introduced a plot twist!

Upon entering the next chamber, we discovered five doors, each labeled with one of the five Platonic solids: tetrahedron, cube, octahedron, dodecahedron, and icosahedron. Each door led to a different sublevel within the dungeon. We learned that only one door concealed the exit, while the other four concealed deadly traps. Using what

Write a 500-word creative story: you may include the 4 themes in your story. 

1.)  The girl, a boy, the moon
2.) The girl and the bird
3.) The Girl, a girl, a boy (tragic hero)


  • Write the story with a beginning, middle and end.
  • Think carefully about plot and the structure and order in which you present it.
  • Create the characters, dialogue and settings for each scene and develop the characters so they have a distinctive voice, appearance and personality.

  • The Girl, a girl, a boy (tragic hero)

    Two girls, Kim and Yoon are good friends. They are both kind and friendly, and a little naive. One day, they meet a boy who changes their lives forever.
    The girl, a boy, the moon

    A girl spends her days dreaming about the moon. It is always present to her, whether she is looking at it during the day, or gazing into it at night.

    The girl, a bird

    Once upon a time there was a girl with magical powers. She used the magical powers to help her poor family. She was a good daughter and would go to the woods and pick up mushrooms for her family to eat. One day she was out picking mushrooms when a beautiful bird started to follow her. She tried to get rid of the bird and to make it go away but it continued to follow her. When she got home she went to bed early so she could go to sleep before her parents came home. But that night the bird came to her room and pecked out her eye so she could never see it again.

    The girl, a boy, the moon

    The girl was looking out of her bedroom window. The moon was full and she loved the way it was shining through her room. As she watched the moon, a boy ran past her window. He was running so fast that she didn't have time to say hello before he had disappeared around the corner. She ran out of her room and down the stairs to see him again, but he was already gone. The girl was sad, but she knew that he would come back again someday.

Write a 500-word creative story: "At your 25th high school reunion, your crush finally asks you out to dinner. The two of you discuss your past, present, and future plans. Just as the night is about to end, you agree to watch the stars together.".
Avoid starting with classic sentences like "Once upon a time", be creative. In the heart of New York City, nestled between skyscrapers and bustle, was a small, quaint coffee shop known as Luna’s Delights. Its cozy atmosphere was the perfect setting for romantic encounters, and on this particular evening, the sun had just set as the clock struck six, signaling the end of the school day and the beginning of another romantic rendezvous for its patrons.

As patrons made their way to their usual tables, an air of excitement buzzed throughout the room. Amongst them were two longtime high school sweethearts – Mia and Daniel. Both now in their mid-thirties, they met during their freshman year when they first moved into New York City from rural Pennsylvania. Their shared love for art and music brought them together, and by their senior year, they were inseparable, often seen holding hands while strolling down the cobblestone streets of Manhattan after class.

However, things changed after graduation. They went their separate ways, pursuing different career paths and dreaming of the future. Years passed, and they never forgot the special connection they once shared, always reminiscing about their younger days.

On this night, something magical happened. As Mia entered Luna’s Delights, her eyes scanned the room until they landed on a familiar face – Daniel! Without missing a beat, she approached him, greeted him warmly, and took a seat next to him. He looked great; she felt proud of how far he had come since high school.

The conversation flowed easily, filled with laughter and stories of old, interspersed with lighthearted banter about their current lives. Then came the question Mia had been waiting for all evening: “Would you like to join me tonight to watch the stars?”

Mia hesitated, unsure how to respond. This could mean so many things; did he still feel the same way towards her as he did back in high school? With bated breath, she said yes, agreeing to meet him outside afterward.

Dinner proved to be delicious, full of good conversation, and punctuated with moments of silence where each contemplated their respective futures. After dessert, they stepped outside into the cool

They all had their unique quirks and passions but shared one common interest: solving puzzles. One particular puzzle caught their attention and they decided to come together to form what they fondly called “The Trigonometry Club.”

At the club meetings, Carl would challenge himself to create geometric designs using his circular saw while Daisy would dance around them gracefully, making them come alive with movement. As for Ethan, he would analyze these shapes, measuring angles and lengths meticulously before sharing his insights with the rest of the group. Together, they formed a harmonious trio, each bringing something special to the table.

One day, during a heated discussion about whether the sine function has any limit points within its domain, Carl suddenly dropped his planer onto the ground, causing it to malfunction. He exclaimed, “Oh no! I forgot to check if my tool works properly after sitting idle for so long!”

Daisy smiled reassuringly and said, “Don't worry, let me help you out, dear friend. You see, I am quite familiar with the inverse operation since our ballerina corps teaches us how to calculate missing angles through various dance poses and routines.”

With that encouragement, Ethan spoke up confidently, “Well then, since we know that sin^-1(x) exists only when -1 <= x <= 1, we can conclude that there aren't any potential issues with your tool because every point lies within that range according to your problem statement.”
